summary: Avengers Cast Savagely Roast Brie Larson & Her Lies About Doing Her Own ...  Wait, ugly, older bearded and spiteful man hates on...
caption:
Avengers Cast Savagely Roast Brie Larson & Her Lies About Doing Her Own …

Wait, ugly, older bearded and spiteful man hates on Brie Larson.

I didn’t realize they made a sequel to Room.

‘Now lets focus on her body language! Her own butt had a stunt double! Who talks about this!? What is wrong with her body? And didn’t that co-star look at her once in a way that is strange.’ 

Fucking creepy how he in-depth examines every interview. This man is a stalker. And obsessive.

blog.name: a-simple-imagine
blog.title:
Just Let Me Go...
Its Okay
blog.description: Alice. 22. I channel my sad energy into reader inserts for TV/film Characters. Currently ACCEPTING requests. Masterlist

title: 6. After Sex Kisses
body:
Requested by me: Gentle kisses shared between the reader and Carol after sex as they discuss their dinner plans

Pairing: Carol Danvers x reader

Words: 377

TRIGGER WARNING - Suggestive themes, I guess

You lay drowning in the fading smell of sex and sweat. Limbs tangled. A lazy smile resting on your lips as you stare at the ceiling above. You hear your girlfriend shuffle on the bed beside you, turning onto her side and propping her head up on her elbow.

“Are you okay?” She wonders quietly as you turn to look at her. The blonde leans in and gently presses her lips to yours in a slow and tender embrace.

“Mhmm,” You nod as she pulls away. “Never better.”

“Do you want some water or something?”

You shuffle closer to the naked woman; shaking your head as you place your hand on her jaw and reconnect your lips. Carol smiles against your lips.

“What do you wanna do for dinner?” You ask, resting your head on your girlfriend’s chest. Carol’s fingers dance over your bare stomach drawing little invisible shapes.

“Maybe we should just go out?”

“I’m not sure my legs will get me that far,” You tease and you can just tell Carol is wearing a smirk. Lips gently press against the top of your head.

“How about we just order a pizza?” the blonde mumbles lowly; moving to place a kiss against your flushed cheek. “Maybe some mozzarella sticks.” Carol moves from underneath you and you fall flat against the mattress. Turning so you lay on your back, she climbs on top of you. “We can cuddle.” Her teeth nip at the skin of your collarbone before she buries her face in the crook of your neck. “We could put on a movie and just… relax.” Her teeth sink into your skin earning a gentle moan. You lose yourself in the feeling as she begins to pepper little quick kisses all over your body. You squirm a little under her touch. Maybe she’s trying to start something again. You reach out for her when she reaches your hips in order to get her to stop which she does; immediately before crawling up your body. Resting on your lower torso, her palms run over your chest. Staring down at you with nothing short of admiration in her eyes.

“That sounds perfect.” You reply, gently kissing her hand. “Can we get ice cream too?”

“Anything you want baby girl.”

summary:
So I read Monica Rambeau's first appearance in, weirdly enough, The Amazing Spider-man Annual #16.
I don't know how I've never...
body:
So I read Monica Rambeau’s first appearance in, weirdly enough, The Amazing Spider-man Annual #16.

I don’t know how I’ve never heard this before but she’s introduced by Peter being a creep and stalking her out of the bus station where he’s waiting for his friends because he thinks she’s hot lmao

Plenty of time to follow this unsuspecting young woman from a distance! Not pervy at all!

Well obviously she does get accosted by thugs and handles them easily herself, which launches into her origin story, the best part of which is that her costume comes from a Mardi Gras fancy dress storage room.

And Monica introducing herself as Captain Marvel, somehow completely unaware of the other famous superhero Captain Marvel who just died recently enough for the copyright on the name not to expire.

summary: Captain Marvel is Not a Villain
title: Captain Marvel is Not a Villain
body:
But she isn’t a good superhero, either. [NOTE: I’m talking in the context of the MCU itself here, not Carol as a character]

So what do I mean by this? Well, first we have to establish what makes a good superhero:

  1. Being good at your job
    This one is kind of obvious, but a superhero obviously needs to be good at saving people in order to be considered “good” in their field of work. Captain Marvel, without question, is good at this aspect of her work- she stands up for those who need her and she’s incredibly powerful, so this comes quite easy for her.
  2. Doing the most they can to help others
    Whether or not Captain Marvel is self-sacrificing or selfless is debatable, but so is that aspect being crucial to a good superhero. However, Captain Marvel does help others in larger ways than your bog-standard police officer (in the sense that she is capable of and willing to help many more than someone in the police force could do individually or as a member of a collective). So the problem with her “hero-ness” isn’t here, either.
  3. Being responsible
    We all know the line: ”With great power comes great responsibility”. We haven’t seen Captain Marvel do anything in the MCU so far that contradicts this idea, so it’s impossible to say for definite of this version of Captain Marvel acts both responsibly and holds herself responsible to her mistakes, so this point has to be ignored.
  4. Being a good role model
    This is the one for me that is the biggest red flag, as a superhero is supposed to act as a figurehead for all that is good and just in the world, such as Superman in the DC comics or Captain America (at least in the war) in the MCU. It’s arguably one of the most important aspects of a superhero, so whether or not Captain Marvel is one to not only young children but also adults and every other group in society is incredibly important. So let’s dissect this:

The main turnoff for me is this scene:

I know- gross.

This guy is definitely in the wrong, of course. What he says is offensive and sexist and shouldn’t be tolerated, that I completely agree on.

What I don’t agree on, however, is Carol’s actions following this comment he makes. She steals his motorbike. Let me say that one more time:

SHE STEALS HIS MOTORBIKE.

Don’t get me wrong, the guy deserves a good slap in the face or a few nights in the county jail cell, but certainly not having his multi-thousand dollar bike stolen from him!

I’m not saying we should be teaching young girls to tolerate comments like this, of course, we shouldn’t. What I’m saying is that if Carol did this as a fully fledged superhero later in her carer, imagine the ideas impressionable kids could get from this:

“Hey! A guy wolf whistles at you? COMMIT GRAND THEFT IN PUBLIC DAYLIGHT! Wha- oh, no, it’s fine! Captain Marvel does that.”

I know I’m exaggerating here, but it’s essentially what she does in this scene- Carol needlessly escalated the conflict to the point where, in a court of law, she would be more in the wrong than this guy would be. Because at the end of the day, theft of a Harley Davidson is more wrong than one dickhead being a dickhead, no matter the reason for the theft. And that isn’t something a role model would do. They would be the bigger person or at least retaliate in equal measure, not escalate a negative situation.

So what’s my point here?

Well, if you tally up the points from the other factors I laid out, Captain Marvel isn’t a bad superhero: she has two of the four points for definite, and probably a third, to an extent. But I wouldn’t say she’s a good superhero either- they should have all of these points, or at least three full ones.

So, like I said:

She’s not a villain, but she’s not a good superhero, either.

  2. Doing the most they can to help others
    Whether or not Captain Marvel is self-sacrificing or selfless is debatable, but so is that aspect being crucial to a good superhero. However, Captain Marvel does help others in larger ways than your bog-standard police officer (in the sense that she is capable of and willing to help many more than someone in the police force could do individually or as a member of a collective). So the problem with her “hero-ness” isn’t here, either.
  3. Being responsible
    We all know the line: ”With great power comes great responsibility”. We haven’t seen Captain Marvel do anything in the MCU so far that contradicts this idea, so it’s impossible to say for definite of this version of Captain Marvel acts both responsibly and holds herself responsible to her mistakes, so this point has to be ignored.
  4. Being a good role model
    This is the one for me that is the biggest red flag, as a superhero is supposed to act as a figurehead for all that is good and just in the world, such as Superman in the DC comics or Captain America (at least in the war) in the MCU. It’s arguably one of the most important aspects of a superhero, so whether or not Captain Marvel is one to not only young children but also adults and every other group in society is incredibly important. So let’s dissect this:

The main turnoff for me is this scene:

I know- gross.

This guy is definitely in the wrong, of course. What he says is offensive and sexist and shouldn’t be tolerated, that I completely agree on.

What I don’t agree on, however, is Carol’s actions following this comment he makes. She steals his motorbike. Let me say that one more time:

SHE STEALS HIS MOTORBIKE.

Don’t get me wrong, the guy deserves a good slap in the face or a few nights in the county jail cell, but certainly not having his multi-thousand dollar bike stolen from him!

I’m not saying we should be teaching young girls to tolerate comments like this, of course, we shouldn’t. What I’m saying is that if Carol did this as a fully fledged superhero later in her carer, imagine the ideas impressionable kids could get from this:

“Hey! A guy wolf whistles at you? COMMIT GRAND THEFT IN PUBLIC DAYLIGHT! Wha- oh, no, it’s fine! Captain Marvel does that.”

I know I’m exaggerating here, but it’s essentially what she does in this scene- Carol needlessly escalated the conflict to the point where, in a court of law, she would be more in the wrong than this guy would be. Because at the end of the day, theft of a Harley Davidson is more wrong than one dickhead being a dickhead, no matter the reason for the theft. And that isn’t something a role model would do. They would be the bigger person or at least retaliate in equal measure, not escalate a negative situation.

So what’s my point here?

Well, if you tally up the points from the other factors I laid out, Captain Marvel isn’t a bad superhero: she has two of the four points for definite, and probably a third, to an extent. But I wouldn’t say she’s a good superhero either- they should have all of these points, or at least three full ones.

So, like I said:

She’s not a villain, but she’s not a good superhero, either.
trail.content_abstract: But she isn’t a good superhero, either. [NOTE: I’m talking in the context of the MCU itself here, not Carol as a character]

summary: could i get a marvel ship? i’m a lesbian, i’m 5’5”, and short fluffy hair. i play piano, clarinet, and i also sing and draw. i...
question: could i get a marvel ship? i’m a lesbian, i’m 5’5”, and short fluffy hair. i play piano, clarinet, and i also sing and draw. i have a fear of people hating me but i always end up doing something to make everyone hate me and ive been told i’m obnoxious. i try to please everyone before myself and i know i should stop but i just can’t and i need someone to help with that. i’m never in the bed mental state but i’m trying to fix that. very random but i say swiggity swag a lot. thank you !!
answer: Ship you with Carol Danvers!! She would immediately help you with your fear of people hating you by every single day telling you how much you mean to her and why you’re an absolute badass woman!
